column1: "topics": " Jejomar Binay
"question": "Philippines: How does it feel if you are a relative of VP Binay and keep hearing all the negative sentiment against him?"
"answers": "I have two answers for this.My bad side: I would want my relative to win so he can give me more \"blessings\". You know
column2: that think he's known for. Probably
column3: I would even help him campaign in his vote buying method. Of course
column4: I care what the people say. He has the same blood as I have. I would really feel bad.My good side: I would confront him and try to let him spill out the truth but I probably wouldn't reveal it to the public because he is my family. If I do reveal it
column5: I would do it anonymously.Written 23 Mar"

column1: "topics": " Text Mining
"question": "How do I label the documents that will be used as training data for classification?"
"answers": "You have a tag field.\u00a0 You read the document.\u00a0 You come to a conclusion that the document is positive or negative with respect to person X. You put the appropriate code - +/-
column2: pos/neg - in the tag field.\u00a0 Creating training data is a manual process.Written Jul 19
column3: 2015 \u2022 View Upvotes \u2022 Answer requested by 1 personHire two or more annotators. Come up with steps or a methodology for these annotators to annotate documents. A methodology can include sample examples about how to annotate documents. The objective is to train the annotators. Once these documents are annotated compute their agreement. The standard approach to use is Kappa Score. If the agreement is more than 81% choose anyone annotator's labels. That will be your ground truth. Many people compute an average for multiple annotators to determine the ground truth. Written Feb 26Not 100% sure what you are asking but you can use clustering to label your documents. You can create a corpus and after cleanup you can create DocumentTermMatrix. And then cluster the document based on attributes of your subjective classification. You can assign the cluster it belongs as label.Written Mar 4"

column6: meaning the detection can handle slang

column1: "topics": " Natural Language Toolkit (NLTK)
"question": "Is NLTK suitable for big data?"
"answers": "NLTK can be used with big data processing engine like Apache Spark
column2: but only in a standalone mode
column3: that is to stay on a single machine on a\u00a0 single consolidated data set. NLTK can't be used for distributed processing. You can't use NLTK on a cluster.Written Oct 1
column4: 2015 \u2022 View UpvotesIf you mix NLTK with a Big Data processing platform like Spark or Hive
column5: you can do yourself some good. (For example
column6: on Spark you could write a procedure using pySpark and include calls to NLTK that perform key operations on data at the right scale.)Your mileage may vary.\u00a0---vWritten Sep 12
column8: I would use APIs like enterprise versions of Spacy or Alchemy as they can compute a lot on the cloud for you. So you do not have to use your own resources for computation. Written Apr 23NLTK is pure python. It can be a little slow. If it is suitable or not really depends on the scale that you intend to use it for.Written Jul 15

column1: "topics": " Sentiment Analysis
"question": "How do you think an intelligent machine would be able to detect sarcasm and irony during sentiment analysis?"
"answers": "See ICWSM - A Great Catchy Name: Semi-Supervised Recognition of Sarcastic Sentences in Product Reviews. It is a paper about sarcasm detection
column2: chosen number 14 in the 50 best inventions of 2010 by TIME magazine.Written Feb 24 \u2022 View UpvotesIt's really quite remarkable. It took me several years to design and test the algorithm to understand sarcasm. It started by look at the root of what sarcasm is
column3: understanding why we use it as humans and how we developed it in our language. It was through this research I was able to discover the basics of detecting sarcasm. I integrating it into our search engine (Enginuity) and further refined the algorithm as we analyzing over billion pieces of content from the internet.Written Feb 24 \u2022 View Upvotes \u2022 Answer requested by  Tony OkothI actually programmed some basic sarcasm detection A.I. using sentiment analysis
column4: and explain how in this article: \"Computers can not...\": Understand sarcasm Written Feb 12 \u2022 View Upvotes"
